urn:contentItem:5HSM-0KV1-DY2K-G11W-00000-00Techno-skeptics slowly powering upDigital dissenters laud technology, lament its fallout2016-01-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:28ZLexisNexisA SECTIONFLORIDAPg. A2Techno-skeptics slowly powering up
Digital dissenters laud technology, lament its falloutJoel Achenbach, The Washington Post

Astra Taylor's iPhone has a cracked screen. She has bandaged it with clear packing tape and plans to use the phone until it disintegrates. She objects to the planned obsolescence of today's gadgetry and to the way the big tech companies pressure customers to upgrade.

Taylor, 36, is a documentary filmmaker, musician and political activist. She's also an emerging star in the world of technology criticism. She's not paranoid, but she keeps duct tape over the camera lens on her laptop -- because, as everyone knows, these gadgets can be taken over by nefarious agents of all kinds.

Taylor is a 21st-century digital dissenter. She's one of the many technophiles unhappy about the way the tech revolution has played out. Political progressives once embraced the utopian promise of the Internet as a democratizing force, but they've been dismayed by the rise of the "surveillance state," and the near monopolization of digital platforms by huge corporations.

Last month, Taylor and more than 1,000 activists, scholars and techies gathered at the New School in New York City to talk about reinventing the Internet. They dream of a co-op model: people dealing directly with one another without going through a data-sucking corporate hub.

We need a movement, Taylor told the conferees at the close of the two-day session, "that says no to the existing order."

Some digital dissenters aren't focused on the economic issues, but simply on the nature of human-machine interactions: Because of their devices, people are constantly distracted. They're rarely fully present anywhere.

Other critics are alarmed by the erosion of privacy. Revelations in 2013 by former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden incited widespread fear of government surveillance.

Some dissenters think technology is driving economic inequality. There are grave concerns that robots are taking the jobs of humans. And the robot issue leads to the most apocalyptic fear: that machine intelligence could run away from its human inventors, leaving people enslaved by the machines they created.

One of the tech world's top advocates in Washington, D.C., is Rob Atkinson, president of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, which receives about two-thirds of its funding from tech companies.

Atkinson worries that books by people such as Astra Taylor will create a thought contagion that will infect Washington policymaking. In his view, there are two types of Luddites: the old-fashioned hand-wringers who are spooked by anything new and innovative; and the "soft" Luddites who say they embrace technology but want to go slower, with more European-style regulations.

The dean of the digital dissenters, meanwhile, is Jaron Lanier, 55. He's a musician, composer, performer and pioneer of virtual reality headsets that allow the user to experience computer-generated 3-D environments. But what he's most famous for is his criticism of the computer culture he helped create.

He believes that Silicon Valley treats humans like electrical relays in a vast machine. Although he still works in technology, he largely has turned against his tribe.

Lanier has written books saying everyone essentially works for Facebook, Google, etc., by feeding material into those central processors and turning private lives into something corporations can monetize. He'd like to see people compensated for their data in the form of micropayments.

Other tech critics have rolled their eyes at that.

urn:contentItem:5VJG-2X91-F12F-F24T-00000-00Tech of tomorrow revealed : Virtusa's Trend Almanac identifies top digital investment trends for 20192019-03-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:28ZLexisNexisTech of tomorrow revealed : Virtusa's Trend Almanac identifies top digital investment trends for 2019SRI LANKA

SRI LANKA, March 3 -- VirtusaxLabs, an innovation practice within Virtusa, has identified the 10 most influential technology trends that industry, business and tech leaders need to know as they strategically plan their investments over the next 12 months. Virtusa xLabs collaborated with senior technologists and business leaders to identify the most influential technology trends that will help businesses to stay competitive and drive growth in 2019.

The trends also expose new business imperatives that leaders need to capitalise on to remain competitive in the evolving digital economy. "Being successful in the digital economy requires a transformation that goes beyond embracing emerging technologies," EVP and global head of Virtusa xLabs, Senthil Ravindran said.

"It demands a new way of thinking, a design mindset that applies new technologies and agile processes to transform experiences while maintaining privacy and security. With the pace of change accelerating, leaders need to embrace evolving technologies and remain willing to rapidly iterate and experiment. Traditional business methods that worked a decade ago, are no longer effective in today's agile digital environment," he said.

Virtusa xLabs analysed over 150 sources from industry experts, trend spotters and analyst firms to help business and technology leaders to prepare better for the wave of digital disruption.

Crossing the next AI frontier: The release of open source DRL libraries last year is set to spur the development of commercial applications for AI. As a result, deep reinforcement learning (DRL), a powerful machine learning tool, will move out of research institutes and into the world of business.

Collaborative Intelligence: What if machines could learn from machines, not just humans? This seemingly far-fetched prospect is becoming a reality. Collaborative intelligence imagines a world of multi-machine-human exponential learning, fuelled by recent breakthroughs in AI.

Open banking adolescence: 2019 is the year when banks and financial institutions start to take the opportunities around Open Banking seriously. A key regulation will be laid down in September, which will mark the beginning of a new era in banking in Europe. Core tenets include interoperability, openness, customer-centricity and innovation.

Finnovation for the developing world: Financial inclusion is about to move into the next phase. The developing world's new digital payment rails have enabled millions to gain access to the formal economy. Regulators, FinTechs, challenger banks and traditional banks have an opportunity to create the products and services to ride on top of those rails and transform whole communities in the process.

Crypto coming of age: Until blue-chip financial giants help to establish the financial infrastructure for crypto-markets, institutional investor participation will remain weak. This year, the world's biggest banks and financial bodies are starting to build those structures, sending a strong signal to market participants and heralding a shift to a higher level of cryptocurrency activity.

Making our data safe again: Many organisations are hoovering up large amounts of personal data to 'hack the minds' of their consumers or sell on their insights to third parties. By the same token, businesses are becoming prime targets for cyber-attacks. In 2019, we expect to see decentralised digital identity products start to gain market traction, giving back control to individuals and organisations.

Never disconnected: 5G will deliver the internet at light-speed. While not expected to replace 4G until 2020, marquee firms are launching 5G smartphones this year. Significantly, this communication protocol is an enabling technology that will accelerate progress with other exponential technologies, such as AI and IoT.

Interlopers in the boardroom: Design is starting to play a strategic role within digital transformation programs. Companies have witnessed the innovations that have arisen from Big Tech's design-led culture and are taking stock. They've also absorbed the fruits of the Design Thinking movement, the spate of CDO appointments and consulting firms' discourse on the centrality of design to successful digital transformations. This year, design will be on the boardroom agenda.

Health data you can trust: Health data management is struggling to keep costs down, remain up-to-date and support patient needs.

The Synaptic Health Alliance, a consortium of leading healthcare organisations, is applying blockchain to improve Provider Data Management. This will be a key test in the uptake of blockchain solutions for the sector.

Omniscient Healthcare: The connected health market is rapidly transforming. Invisibles, a non-invasive wireless device, is causing waves with its ability to analyse the reams of data that your body transmits in the comfort of your home. Wearables, telemedicine platforms, apps, or other digital healthcare services and the connected health ecosystem are maturing rapidly and will have a much bigger impact in 2019.

The Almanac contains some leftfield trends that will stimulate fresh thinking for innovation projects. It provides an overview of the technology trends to give readers a rounded understanding of the trend landscape for 2019.

Collaborative intelligence, finnovation for the developing world and crypto-coming-of-age among top ten trends to look out for in the year ahead LONDON, UK - (February 26, 2019) Virtusa xLabs, an innovation practice within Virtusa, has identified the 10 most influential technology trends that industry, business, and tech leaders need to know as they strategically plan their investments over the next 12 months. Virtusa xLabs collaborated with senior technologists and business leaders to identify the most influential technology trends that will help businesses to stay competitive and drive growth in 2019. These trends also expose new business imperatives that leaders need to capitalise on in order to remain competitive in the evolving digital economy. "Being successful in the digital economy requires a transformation that goes beyond embracing emerging technologies," said Senthil Ravindran, EVP and global head of Virtusa xLabs. He adds, "It demands a new way of thinking.

A design mindset that applies new technologies and agile processes to transform experiences while maintaining privacy and security. With the pace of change accelerating, leaders need to openly embrace evolving technologies and remain willing to rapidly iterate and experiment. Traditional business methods that worked a decade ago, are no longer effective when applied in today's agile digital environment." Virtusa xLabs analysed over 150 sources from industry experts, trend spotters, and analyst firms to help business and technology leaders to prepare better for the oncoming wave of digital disruption:

Crossing the next AI frontier: The release of open source DRL libraries last year is set to spur the development of commercial applications for AI. As a result, deep reinforcement learning (DRL), a powerful machine learning tool, will move out of research institutes and into the world of business.

Collaborative Intelligence: What if machines could learn from machines, not just humans? This seemingly far-fetched prospect is now becoming a reality. Collaborative intelligence imagines a world of multi-machine-human exponential learning, fuelled by recent breakthroughs in AI.

Open banking adolescence: 2019 is the year when banks and financial institutions start to take the opportunities around Open Banking seriously. A key regulation will be laid down in September, which will mark the beginning of a new era in banking in Europe. Core tenets include interoperability, openness, customer-centricity and innovation.

Finnovation for the developing world: Financial inclusion is about to move into the next phase. The developing world's new digital payment rails has enabled millions to gain access to the formal economy for the first time. Regulators, FinTechs, challenger banks, and traditional banks have an opportunity to create the products and services to ride on top of those rails and transform whole communities in the process.

Crypto coming of age: Until blue-chip financial giants help to establish the financial infrastructure for crypto-markets, institutional investor participation will remain weak. This year, the world's biggest banks and financial bodies are starting to build those structures, sending a strong signal to market participants and heralding a shift to a higher level of cryptocurrency activity.

Making our data safe again: Many organisations are hoovering up large amounts of personal data to "hack the minds" of their consumers or sell on their insights to third parties. By the same token, businesses themselves are becoming prime targets for cyber-attacks. In 2019, we expect to see decentralised digital identity products start to gain market traction, giving back control to individuals and organisations.

Never disconnected: 5G will deliver the internet at light-speed. Whilst not expected to replace 4G until 2020, marquee firms are already launching 5G smartphones this year. Significantly, this communication protocol is an enabling technology that will accelerate progress with other exponential technologies like AI and IoT.

This year, design will be on the boardroom agenda.

urn:contentItem:5B9N-DH91-JDJ6-K22P-00000-00Tech on NSA: Good start, details next2014-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:28ZLexisNexisTech on NSA: Good start, details nextTony Romm

Google, Facebook, Microsoft and other tech giants heard plenty of promise in President Barack Obama's speech on surveillance reform.

Now, they're just waiting for the real details.

The president offered a nod of support Friday to many items on Big Tech's wish list, including a pledge for more transparency about government surveillance requests, new public advocates at the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court and more privacy protections for foreigners.

That's good news for tech companies that fear an erosion of consumer trust and a backlash in Europe and other markets over their perceived cooperation with U.S. government snooping. But many of the president's proposals have yet to be fleshed out -- and may require cooperation from Congress -- signaling more debate to come for the industry.

(Sign up for POLITICO's Morning Tech tip sheet)

"The commitments outlined by President Obama represent positive progress on key issues including transparency from the government and in what companies will be allowed to disclose, extending privacy protections to non-US citizens, and FISA court reform," AOL, Apple, LinkedIn, Microsoft, Facebook, Google, Twitter and Yahoo said in a joint statement after the president's speech.

But, they added, "Crucial details remain to be addressed on these issues, and additional steps are needed on other important issues, so we'll continue to work with the administration and Congress to keep the momentum going and advocate for reforms consistent with the principles we outlined in December."

The companies' response to Edward Snowden's leaks about NSA surveillance has evolved significantly over the past several months, from legalistic statements to demands for more transparency about government surveillance requests to outright lobbying for NSA reform in Washington. Top executives like Apple CEO Tim Cook and Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg made their point directly to the president at the White House last month. And they took out full-page ads in major newspapers highlighting their belief in the need for surveillance reform.

The changing strategy reflects the business pressures created by the surveillance revelations, with regulators worldwide threatening new penalties and market barriers for U.S. tech companies, particularly in Europe, where efforts are underway to toughen consumer privacy rules.

(Also on POLITICO: Full technology policy coverage)

Obama on Friday moved in the direction of tech company positions on multiple fronts. He called for a panel of privacy and technology advocates on the FISC and announced a new position at the State Department "to coordinate our diplomacy on issues related to technology and signals intelligence." The White House also recommitted the administration to defending the "open Internet" internationally.

"What we've been doing over the last few months resonated with the president, and that we've got a lot of work left to do as we turn a lot of these reforms into legislation," said Dean Garfield, CEO of the the Information Technology Industry Council.

Many of the details of the president's plan, however, remain vague.

Obama, for example, emphasized the need for surveillance transparency, a major issue for the industry -- but the White House didn't reveal much about how that would work.

(Also on POLITICO: Lawmakers praise, pan President Obama's NSA plan)

In a statement after the speech, the White House said only that it's aiming to "enable communications providers to make public more information than ever before about the orders they have received to provide data to the government." It said it's still "in discussions with the providers about ways in which additional information could be made public."

The administration has been locked in a legal battle with tech companies at the surveillance court over how much the industry can disclose about government requests.

The White House's plan of action also lacked details on how surveillance court opinions might be made public and specifics on the protections for non-U.S. citizens, according to sources close to the tech companies that issued the joint statement Friday.

Also unresolved: how the intelligence community will meet the president's call to minimize incidental collection of Americans' emails and other communications as the NSA pursues foreign targets. And the administration said nothing about the issue of encryption, which has sparked criticism in the tech industry after reports that NSA has sought to crack a range of devices and services.

The president at one point appeared to open the door to scrutiny of commercial as well as government data collection -- something that could subject tech giants to unwanted questions.

"Corporations of all shapes and sizes track what you buy, store and analyze our data and use it for commercial purposes; that's how those targeted ads pop up on your computer or smartphone," Obama said in his speech.

The president announced a new presidential task force to study "big data," led by top adviser John Podesta and other officials. The review will look at how the public and private sectors are confronting the "challenges" to privacy in an age where computers can process and analyze once unfathomable troves of information about people.

urn:contentItem:5T6B-DCW1-JB20-G3FV-00000-00Tech on the Hill; Tropical Storm Gordon; Supreme Court Showdown; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; Toyota Recalling More than one Million Vehicles; CDC: More Sick from Kellogg; A Starbucks Run by Seniors2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:28ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMike Murphy, Bob Nardelli, Pete Pachal, Hank Greenburg, Troy GayeskiNEWSFinancial090502cb.231Tech on the Hill; Tropical Storm Gordon; Supreme Court Showdown; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; Toyota Recalling More than one Million Vehicles; CDC: More Sick from Kellogg; A Starbucks Run by SeniorsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Steve Harrigan, Andrew Napolitano, Cheryl Cason

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, September 5th. Your top stories right now, just after 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Tech goes to Capitol Hill today. Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg and Twitter's Jack Dorsey will be questioned this morning on possible foreign influence over social media and accusations of political bias.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I don't think it's about election. I think what it's really about free speech.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If the conservatives just leave, then only the liberal voices will be on Twitter. And Twitter's a very powerful tool.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We are bringing you the hearings live this morning right here on Fox Business. Join us for that.

Plus, trade tensions with Canada and China weighing on markets this morning.

Futures are off of the low right now, down about 80 points but still underwater given this nervousness over the trade deals that we are waiting for. Dow Industrials set to open down about 80 points, S&P 500 down 6, and the Nasdaq down 20.

This, after a mostly flat close for the markets yesterday -- take a look at market performance where The Nasdaq was the worst performer, down a quarter of a percent with an 18-point decline.

In Europe this morning, similar story -- money coming out of equities. FT 100 down a third of a percent, CAC 40 in Paris down almost 1 percent, and the DAX index down one-half of a percent in Germany.

Asian markets also in the red overnight, worst performer Hong Kong, as you can see.

Meanwhile Tropical Storm Gordon has turned deadly. The tropical storm has killed a child and left thousands of others without power. The very latest forecast coming up.

Plus, do not eat, do not buy Honey Smacks Cereal. That is the warning from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. You want to hear this. The very latest on an outbreak as a result of Honey Smacks -- we will tell you about it.

And all ages welcome here, a Starbucks staffed entirely by senior citizens.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning and joining me to break it all down -- our own Dagen McDowell, Rosecliff CEO and managing partner Mike Murphy, and the former CEO of Home Depot and Chrysler Bob Nardelli. Great to see you this morning.

BOB NARDELLI, FORMER CEO OF HOME DEPOT AND CHRYSLER: Great to be with you.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO, ROSECLIFF CAPITAL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: The hour just ran by, this first hour.

NARDELLI: It did. It's amazing.

BARTIROMO: Busy show.

MCDOWELL: Apologies for acting like I got shot out of a cannon at 6:00 in the morning.

BARTIROMO: No, no, no. You were talking about an incident that happened yesterday in the Kavanaugh hearing. And I want to hear more about that because it went viral on the Internet -- Dagen. And we saw the picture of -- what was it -- somebody on his staff sitting behind Brett Kavanaugh when he was sitting there in the testimony.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Zina Bash was her name. And she was accused by many people, left wing nuts I might call them this morning, accused of making a white power symbol with her hand. This perceived white power symbol started out as an Internet hoax created to troll people.

Her husband, Zina Bash's husband is a U.S. attorney and he was forced to issue a denial on Twitter. It's really shocking what has happened. Hold on one second. We're going to talk about --

BARTIROMO: That's ridiculous. There's the picture.

MCDOWELL: We're going to talk about this.

BARTIROMO: It's ridiculous.

MCDOWELL: We're going to talk about this later. But I want to just point out that her husband has had to say "The attacks today on my wife are repulsive." He goes on to say "Zina is Mexican on her mother's side and Jewish on her father's side. She was born in Mexico. Her grandparents were Holocaust survivors. We, of course, have nothing to do with hate groups which aim to terrorize and demean other people."

That is part of what her husband had to say. But again, I think this goes to these hearing that we're going to -- that we're going to see on Capitol Hill today from these social media companies, these executives because I think yesterday was a tipping point where people are sick of this hate spewing and the bile belching by people on the left just to get what they want and they will stop at nothing when it comes to destroying people.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Part of the issue, I think, and tell me if you agree, is that this president is having really good outcomes. And whether or not you like his approach --

NARDELLI: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- when you look at 4.1 percent and 4.2 percent economic growth as a result of the tax cut plan and the rollback in regulations. Or you look at foreign policy and, you know, the judges that he's put on the courts, people are feeling good about the outcomes. And his skeptics, the left, are going insane over that.

NARDELLI: I mean in business, Maria -- we always used talk about people who do things make mistakes. They never make the biggest mistake of all which we saw in the prior administration -- do nothing.

And so, you know, there are some issues out there that people take exception to. But on the whole, 4 percent GDP, regulation rollback, taxes, unemployment -- I mean, you just go down the list of favorability.

BARTIROMO: Right. And so they're attacking -- now they attack a staffer on Kavanaugh's team.

MURPHY: They are. And I think people have to realize what you see on social media, you have to read through it a little bit, like use some common sense because a lot of it is just people trying to get you to think one way a lot of times.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely.

We've got all of that coming up this morning. And joining the conversation, chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Congressman Greg Walden is leading the discussion in the testimony with Jack Dorsey and Sheryl Sandberg. He's going to join us first. Billionaire real estate investor and Equity International founder and chairman, Sam Zell is here. He'll give us his take on the economy and I think he is a seller. Former AIG chairman and CEO Hank Greenburg is here to talk China and the former prime minister of Italy, Mario Monte walks in on the trade discussions happening. Plus Fox news senior judicial analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano weighs in as well.

Don't miss a moment of it. We've got a big two hours coming up.

And we kick it off with this, big tech is testifying. AS I first reported right here, Twitter's CEO Jack Dorsey and Facebook's chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg are headed to Capitol Hill this morning to face a grilling from lawmakers over potential censorship concerns on social media.

President Trump weighed in last week on the importance of transparency when it comes to sharing content online.

I also spoke with House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy about the issue on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

Donald Trump, President of the United States: I think that Google and Facebook and Twitter, I think they treat conservatives and Republicans very unfairly. I think it's a very serious problem because they're really trying to silence a very large part of this country.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CAL), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: If there's a conservative being shut down, that voice is not being heard. And if this is where two-thirds of Americans are getting their news, it's not a fair process and this country believes in fairness. The Internet was created on fairness.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us now to talk more about that is Mashable.com tech editor Pete Pachal. Pete -- Good to see you. Thanks for joining us. Your expectations today?

PETE PACHAL, MASHABLE.COM: Well, it's social media on trial part two, as I like to think of it. Like any sequel, it's probably not going to be quite as satisfying and the story line might be a little more confused.

So basically the last time this happened, Mark Zuckerberg was testifying and we were right in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal. And there was a big focus on data privacy and just fundamentals of how Facebook works. We had the top guy talking about it.

Now we have Sheryl Sandberg and Jack Dorsey. They're both big players, no question but now it's more general stuff about the election and what sort of meddling may happen and sort of the steps they're taking about that as well as what we've just been talking about, this sort of silencing of conservative voices or at least, perceived silencing according to them that sort of may be going on. And they're going to have to answer for what has been called shadow banning, at least in Twitter's case and other things like that, to see if they really do care about like the quality of the conversation on their networks and if they really are being true to the idea of having all voices being heard.

BARTIROMO: What are the downside risks today? I mean What could we see? What's the worst thing that could happen to technology companies in light of all of this?

PACHAL: Well, I mean, there's going to be some gaps, certainly. There's going to be some missteps. But I mean the thing that they need to convince the lawmakers today that they're doing is actually really trying to fix their networks in both ways, really, and trying to sort of facilitate healthy conversation which is what a term Jack Dorsey likes to use. But also ensuring that the sort of wide scale inauthentic behavior like we saw the other week with Iranian and Russian sort of networks on Facebook.

And they were sort of ousted, trying to sort of set the stage for the midterm elections or do some influence, sort of making sure that there's open stuff for authentic behavior and they're shutting down the inauthentic behavior. If they can't show that or they can't be convincing about that, there could be some issues either financially or with regulation down the line.

MCDOWELL: The point I was trying to make earlier, that I was making badly, ineloquently is that Twitter has a bigger problem I think and even Facebook and other social media platforms, maybe Instagram to a lesser extent, people are tired of swimming in the cesspool.

They're just going to turn away from it. There's nothing that Twitter can potentially do to solve that problem. It is nothing but people hurling hate across the political aisle.

And that goes for both sides. And people are sick of it. Because it goes beyond just words. It goes to they're trying to destroy people's lives.

PACHAL: Well I agree with you to a large extent. Because, you know, there's a question about just how much does Twitter even control Twitter? Because basically these outrage mobs that we're seeing are an outgrowth of some of the fundamental ways that Twitter works.

BARTIROMO: Well, they knocked Candace Owens off of the platform.

PACHAL: Well yes. And the stance (ph) -- here's what Twitter is really inadvertently good at doing is amplifying extreme points of view; whether it's on the left or the right.

BARTIROMO: Some of them are not so extreme though -- that's what I'm saying, you know. Some of the points of view are not extreme. Wasn't there a couple of instances where, I mean, they took things off for absolutely no reason and then they said sorry, that was a mistake.

MURPHY: So Pete -- I would ask about that, with the algorithms. Initially they're set up by humans. So, you know, Jack Dorsey's talked about it, yes, we have a left-leaning bias at Twitter. Is there a way to get Twitter to a point where there is no bias or is it ok with the bias, in your opinion?

PACHAL: Well, I mean it's hard to say to what extent the bias exists. I mean certainly there is a bias --

BARTIROMO: Well, he said -- he said yes, we're left-leaning.

PACHAL: Yes. I mean the company is. But can those algorithms be programmed to be fair regardless? I think they can to some extent. And I think they also need to -- I think Facebook actually does this better in the sense that they want moderators in the regions of the places where they are rather than having everyone in northern California make the call on content and using like one filter. They want multiple filters throughout.

Now, Twitter is a smaller company. And they don't have the same resources Facebook has. But that kind of approach where you don't have like a bunch of people in an office in northern California making these hard decisions about content, I think it's probably the way -- a good start, anyway.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Bob.

NARDELLI: If there is to be regulation, you just mentioned some best practices, should the government pick those best practices and impose that? I mean what would you like to see coming out of this hearing?

PACHAL: Big question, yes. I mean in terms of the government stepping in, I think, you know, obviously you want to keep that to a minimum. I think stuff with regard to elections is probably the most likely regulation we're going to see on the social networks.

But I would love to see a set of best practices come out from at least one of these networks and I think Facebook is kind of leading the charge here, mostly because they've been hammered the most and have thrown the most resources against it and hopefully see other networks adopt that.

But Twitter sort of has a totally different role than Facebook. I mean it's similar but they're more of a news curator. And like I was saying earlier there's so many things inherent to Twitter that sort of go against healthy conversation like we've seen it over the years with bullying, with abuse, people getting kicked off the platform or just leaving the platform because of all that.

MCDOWELL: Well, this issue censorship, if you want to call it that, I know that the people who quibble over censorship is when it's done by a government.

But what Facebook does is more insidious. They made money. They've shown reckless disregard for people's most personal information for years and years and years. And that's how they make money.

They basically are selling in one way, shape or form your behavior, your most personal data about yourself and they let literally tens of millions people's accounts were compromised because app developers were able to access not only people's data who download the app but the friends' data as well.

That data is out there.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It's spread around the world. Twitter -- not Twitter-- Facebook doesn't even know where it is.

NARDELLI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: By the way, where is Google? Where's Google in all of this? Wasn't -- you know, during the California primary, if you Google California GOP what are the ideologies? A list of ideologies comes up and one of the ideologies was Nazism.

PACHAL: Yes. Google is such a --

BARTIROMO: That's not a coincidence.

PACHAL: -- vast, sprawling company at this point. I'm willing to sort of - - like there were other accusations of Bernie Sanders versus Hillary Clinton and there was a thing where the results that came up Bernie Sanders was sort of disadvantaged.

BARTIROMO: Well, if you Googled Hillary Clinton it was all good stories. If you Googled Donald Trump it was evil, evil, evil. I mean, you know, so there's that as well. It seems to me -- they're a media company, if they abuse their power, there will be consequences. Whether that's regulatory or money, financial -- we don't know.

PACHAL: Yes. And I don't think there's a room at Google where people are coming in and picking and choosing this stuff. But I do think some of the steps they take to, say, prevent misinformation, like if something is written about you that's false, I would not like that to appear in an auto complete or a search result.

So they have tools to sort of push that down. But I do think some of that does sort of get mixed in with this political stuff and that's where things can get really dicey.

BARTIROMO: Pete -- great to get your insights. Thank you -- Pete Pachal.

Stay with us, live coverage of the Dorsey and Sandberg testimonies today; they're testifying before Congress at 9:30 a.m. Eastern. We'll have that.

Tropical storm Gordon slams the Gulf Coast. That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are coming off of the lows. We are still looking at a lower opening for the broader averages. Trade tensions with Canada and China unnerving investors this morning.

Dow Industrials set to open down about 75 points. The S&P is down 5 and the Nasdaq lower by 18.

Meanwhile, there's this, tropical storm Gordon is slamming the Gulf Coast with heavy rain, powerful winds.

Fox News correspondent Steve Harrigan is live in Orange Beach, Alabama this morning with the very latest. Steve -- good morning to you.

STEVE HARRIGAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning -- Maria.

Over the last hour or so we've seen conditions gradually weaken here along the coast of Alabama, some wind gusts of 10 to 20 miles an hour, big surf behind me, four to six feet high, crashing into that pier. The rain has been on and off.

Tropical Storm Gordon hit last night at 10:00 p.m. It made landfall on the border between Mississippi and Alabama as a powerful tropical storm. Sustained wind speeds of 70 miles an hour -- that's just under a category 1 hurricane but not as bad as some people predicted.

As far as the damage goes, at least one person killed by the storm in Pensacola, a tree came down on a mobile home, killing a child.

Here in Alabama, many people waking up to no power in their house, at least 20,000 people in Alabama without power.

The real concern now is from the rain. It's been eight to twelve inches in some areas. But this is a quick moving storm and right now it is moving north. So we could see some rain and flooding across the state of Mississippi over the next 24 hours. Maria -- back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Steve -- we'll be watching that. Thanks so much -- Steve Harrigan this morning in Alabama.

Coming up, Supreme Court showdown, we break down Judge Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation hearing yesterday. The circus that it was, protests from Democrats across the board.

Then Toyota recalls over 1 million cars worldwide. Details on the vehicles plagued with a fire risk later this hour.

Back in a moment, right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, it is a Supreme Court showdown. Democrats tirelessly demanding to delay judge Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation proceedings yesterday, interrupting legislators, insisting for more time to review documents on the nominee, protesters spiraled out of control, causing massive disruptions, even before being escorted out by authorities. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Please vote no. Please vote no.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Kavanaugh must not be put on the court.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This (INAUDIBLE) is an attack on women's rights. It's an attack on democracy. Shut the hearing down now, I urge you. Shut the hearing down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Police arrested at least 70 protesters yesterday. This is the first day of week-long hearings.

Joining us right now Judge Andrew Napolitano, Fox News senior judicial analyst. Judge' it's great to see you.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: And that was only half of it. When Grassley first welcomed everybody -- the, you know, interruptions, wanting to just stop the hearing all together from three senators. It was just incredible. Your reaction.

NAPOLITANO: So I have a couple of views. I think to the general public it's government at its worst. I think it really shows how low and base and combative and unresponsive to the needs of the American people our elected representatives can be.

If you go a little deeper into the weeds, I think the Democrats have concluded that they're more likely than not to lose this and Judge Kavanaugh will soon be Justice Kavanaugh. So since they can't really lay a glove on him, they want to attack the process.

Now, some of their complaints about the process are legitimate. I mean dumping 42,000 pages of documents on somebody 12 hours before the hearing is a task impossible. And many of those documents were stamped with may not be discussed in public. Well, what's the sense of surrendering a document if it can't be discussed?

BARTIROMO: Sort of like redacting everything.

NAPOLITANO: Yes. Yes, exactly. But I think the Democrats must have taken a poll and decided that their base wanted to see this kind of acerbic, in- your-face, obstreperous, anything we can do to slow this down type of behavior because it certainly didn't gain any traction with members of the Senate.

There are three members of the Senate being targeted here -- Rand Paul because the Democrats are hoping that on some of these documents there's something Brett Kavanaugh said in the Bush years supportive of torture. That would upset Senator Paul.

They're also looking for something that might upset Senator Collins and Senator Murkowski -- and that would be some antipathy toward Roe versus Wade.

They also understand that it looks bad if you hold back a document -- it looks like you have something to hide. I don't think he has anything to hide.

BARTIROMO: It didn't hurt the FBI or DOJ yet.

NAPOLITANO: It's not his personal decision not to surrender this. Under the Presidential Records Act of 1974, an act that shortly after Richard Nixon resigned the presidency, you need permission from two people to release presidential records -- the person who was president at the time the records are made and the person was president at the time the records were demanded.

George W. Bush, who was the president at the time these were made, signed off on everything. He doesn't care. Donald Trump said 100,000 of these -- I don't want the public to seem them. I'm claiming executive privilege.

It's a little silly for him to claim executive privilege on a historic document that precedes his presidency for 15 years, I think. But he has the right to do that.

Today, however, we're going to see the Q and A directly in his face. You're going to see a very bright judicial mind, but one that is frustrated because he doesn't want to reveal how he stands on hot button issues like guns, like the administrative state, like abortion, like torture.

BARTIROMO: It's getting in there -- Judge. You know, Zina Bash, we talked about this earlier, one of Brett Kavanaugh's former law clerks -- she's under severe scrutiny. Look at this picture right here.

A video circulated of her making -- she had her hands folded and some on the left were saying it was a hand gesture. They said it was a white power sign that she was putting there.

Bash's husband is a U.S. attorney. He came to her defense. And he tweeted this in part, Zina is Mexican on her mother's side and Jewish on her father's side. She was born in Mexico. Her grandparents were holocaust survivors. We of course have nothing to do with hate groups which aim to terrorize and demean other people. Never have and never would."

MCDOWELL: Let me add to this. He called the attacks on my wife repulsive. "Some of the Twitter comments have even referred to our baby daughter."

NAPOLITANO: Wow.

MCDOWELL: I know that there are good folks on both sides of the political divide. I hope that people will clearly condemn this idiotic and sickening accusation. And the people -- you know what, the people on the left who are perpetrating this lie, perpetuating this lie online, this is what people actually see. They're not sitting and watching these hearings all day long -- Judge.

NAPOLITANO: Well I -- first of all I agree fully with the defense by the U.S. attorney of his wife's behavior. I mean this is just over the top.

But it shows the decision of the Democrats and the hard left in this country to do anything they can to tarnish this candidate. What are they really trying to tarnish? The person who nominated the candidate. What are they really trying to undo relitigate, revote -- what ever phrase you want to use undo election of 2016.

This woman is the last woman that would be showing a white power symbol in that environment.

MCDOWELL: Even the Anti-Defamation League had to come out and that said this symbol thing is a hoax.

NAPOLITANO: I have to tell you, though --

MCDOWELL: It was created online. By the way, all these people online, I saw them, these are well-known individuals who should know better, passing this information around while they're online. Go on Amazon and see if can buy a soul.

BARTIROMO: To me it seems like desperation. I think they're worried about the midterm elections.

NAPOLITANO: I think you're right. They must believe that this type of in your face, uncivil behavior will generate support among their base. It doesn't with me. It doesn't with Republicans. I don't know if it does with moderates. But somehow they think that this is going to help them with their own people.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's make a lot of noise so that you forget that your paycheck is higher and the economic situation is a lot better.

Judge -- you know, it's good to see you. Thank you so much.

NAPOLITANO: Thank you. Call again.

BARTIROMO: Judge Napolitano. Coming up, former AIG chairman and CEO Hank Greenberg is with me. He's going to join me to weigh in, on the escalating trade tensions with China, tariffs and a lot more. He's up next.

Then, a wake-up call for your breakfast cereal. Listen up. The new CDC warning for Kellogg's honey smacks. Do not buy them. Do not eat them. Back in a minute.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good morning everybody. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, September 5th. Your top stories right now, 7:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Trade talks with Canada starting back up today. Investors are waiting for another round of tariffs to hit $200 billion in Chinese goods. That may very well be executed this week. The trade tensions are weighing on markets this morning. We're off of the lows but nonetheless we're expecting the Dow Industrials to open down about 80 points, that's one third of one percent. The S&P 500 down a quarter of a percent, and the NASDAQ with av24 point decline down a third of a percent as well. This after mostly flat close yesterday for the markets, Dow Industrials gave up 12 points. It was the NASDAQ that was down 18 the worst performer, a quarter of a percent.

In Europe this morning, markets are lower. Take a look at the European Indices with the worst performer in Paris, CAC Quarante down almost one percent.

The Asian markets also in the red overnight, worst performer was Hong Kong. Hang Seng Index down 2-2/3 percent.

Recall alert, more than one million Toyota vehicles are facing recall this morning after reports that they could cause a fire. Is your car on the list?

Then the CDC is warning do not eat, do not buy, the very latest on Honey Smacks and an outbreak here for the cereal. You'll want to hear the latest from the CDC on that.

And all ages welcome, a Starbucks staffed entirely by senior citizens. All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning.

But first this top story this half an hour, U.S.-China trade tensions front and center. President Trump considering additional tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods as the United States looks to up the pressure on Beijing.

My next guest has some words for Chinese leadership with the recent op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, titled: Some Friendly Advice for Chinese Leaders. You can't expect to keep receiving favorable trade and investment terms unless you reciprocate. Writes, Hank Greenberg.

Joining me right now, is the former CEO and chairman of AIG and the current chairman and CEO of C.V. Starr, Hank Greenburg.

Hank, it's great to see you this morning.

HANK GREENBURG, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, C.V. STARR: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Now, that op-ed obviously comes after an incredible amount of experience. You were the first business person ever to actually set up shop in China and you've had an incredible relationship with Chinese leadership. How do you see the current trade debacle?

GREENBURG: Well, it's unfortunate. China is the second largest economy in the world now. It will soon be the first economy in the world. They have a billion 400 million people. We have 300 million. On size alone and all they've learned in the last 20 and 30 years makes them a candidate to be the largest economy in the world. They can't have the same benefits from us on trade that they had at the beginning. We helped them quite a bit. The op-ed points that out. And I would hope that the Chinese realize that and we come to an agreement.

BARTIROMO: Before we get into some of your solutions and the things that you write in that -- in that piece. Recently we learned that now, the president of China, President Xi is dictator for life. What does that mean to America? Let's talk -- this is a -- this is an important development. You know, we've got a democracy. We're going to be leading -- we're going to be dealing with one leader of China for the rest of his life, certainly, as a dictator. How does that impact things?

GREENBURG: Well, you said it all. He made himself the leader for life. Now, is that going to stick? Remember, there's only about a billion and a half -- million and-a-half communist members in China of a population of a billion, 400 million. Are they going to be satisfied with President Xi for life? Time will tell.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, doesn't it -- they may be -- you know, satisfied or not satisfied. But doesn't that impact the way we deal with China? Given the fact that he doesn't care. He's going to be the leader regardless. He could wait and they're in -- and they're in it for the long run, right?

GREENBURG: Well, maybe. Things change. You know, he -- currently he's the leader for life. Will that -- will that hold? Hard to say.

BARTIROMO: We know that China has been stealing intellectual property from America for a long time, forcing this transfer of technology. They haven't really opened their markets. Now they say in five years you will be able to own an auto company or other -- couple of other industries in China out and out, rather than having a 49 percent stake in a joint venture. What's your take on how fast China is moving in terms of opening its markets to foreigners?

GREENBURG: Very slow. And as what I said in the op-ed, and I'd say that to them face-to-face. They have to have equality now. They've been at it long enough. We've helped them for a long time and it's time -- it's time the market would open for both sides.

BARTIROMO: So, in the op-ed you write the ways that the United States helped China develop over the years.

GREENBURG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Do they recognize that past assistance? Is that going to be helpful in these discussions?

GREENBURG: I think it will be. Because I don't think, you know, many people remember all the things we've done for China.

BARTIROMO: Does China remember?

GREENBURG: Not to say. I think we have to remind them.

BARTIROMO: So, in terms of the intellectual; property theft, they will not admit that they've been actually stealing I.P.

GREENBURG: They don't admit many things, obviously. But, you know, that's going to have to change.

BARTIROMO: So, will it change, though, Hank?

GREENBURG: I think it will. I think it will. Will it -- will it be -- will they change enough to satisfy us? Probably not. But there'll be -- there'll be movement.

BARTIROMO: What does the U.S. need to do? How are you feeling about the potential of an additional $200 billion of tariffs moving on this week?

GREENBURG: Look, the tariff is only one part of trade. Does trade create jobs? Does it help income? There are many things that it does. It's not just the tariffs. I mean, we have to keep that in mind.

BARTIROMO: Have you heard from your colleagues in China the leadership in China, to discuss the ongoing conversations with the U.S.?

GREENBURG: Look, I discuss it all the time with China, with very high level Chinese, and you know, they understand that.

BARTIROMO: And you've met President Xi, obviously.

GREENBURG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Do you think he views China's future as an equal of the United States or something more?

GREENBURG: Could be something more.

BARTIROMO: Yes, tell us about that.

GREENBURG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: How did does he view China? What is he looking to do?

GREENBURG: He wants to make China back to what it was a couple hundred years ago, the Middle Kingdom, at least. And -- but it's going to go beyond that. He wants to control all of Asia, I believe, and, you know, he occupied the South China Sea islands and they're not supposed to be militarized. They are militarized. And so that's a concern. So I think we have -- we have problems with China. We have to resolve them.

BARTIROMO: Well, isn't it also true that they want to be the leader in many of the industries that the U.S. is trying to be the leader in, like A.I., like, you know, certain technology in terms of -- you know, technology, driverless cars, whatever the leading technology is that we're looking at as the growth industries of the future, that's what they want to win.

GREENBURG: Well, you can't blame them for wanting to do that.

BARTIROMO: Right, sure.

GREENBURG: That's a -- it's up to them. Remember, many Chinese went to school in the United States. Thousands of them. They go back, many of them, better educated and more willing to do things that they weren't able to do before. That's normal. But that doesn't mean we have to be enemies. We have to have a constructive relationship with China.

A world with the United States and China as allies is a much safer world than if we're not. And that's an important part of this whole conversation.

BARTIROMO: So, what do you want to say to President Trump as he deals with the leadership in China right now?

GREENBURG: We've got to find a solution. It can't be just increasing tariffs. I mean that's -- China has to recognize, they have to give foreign companies equality in doing business in China, same as they want in our country. And that has to happen. I think most Chinese businessmen understand that now.

BARTIROMO: Because isn't it true that China is now using its economic power for its military complex? You know, we spoke with Devin Nunes, the chairman of the Intel Committee on the House, and he basically said they're creating military bases and complexes right up to sea level, getting their -- the best position across the world, not even near Asia.

GREENBURG: Well, I'm not too worried about that part of it. I think what they've done in the South China Sea is I'm concern.

BARTIROMO: Why? Tell us about that.

GREENBURG: Yes, these little islands that they claim that China over the - - over the centuries had owned, there's no -- there's no evidence of that. If they went to court, in the -- in the world court, and they were denied that they had the right to that, they went ahead anyway.

And it was during the -- during the Obama administration, we did nothing. And now it would be -- now it would be very difficult to extract them from those -- from those islands.

BARTIROMO: In your view, will the U.S. be successful in opening up markets, in getting to -- getting China to change its behavior?

GREENBURG: I'm not sure they'll change their behavior willingly but I think there'll be change in many areas.

BARTIROMO: And if there isn't? They're the two largest economies in the world.

GREENBURG: Then we'll -- then we'll have a trade conflict.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GREENBURG: And it's not in our interest, not in their interest. I saw the other day, -- you now, China is building this one road, one infrastructure around the world.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GREENBURG: I see that we're going to do $60 billion of that ourselves. We just announced it over the weekend.

And so, you know, we do have some conflicts. That's inevitable. But doesn't have to mean that we're enemies. Doesn't have to mean that we don't try to solve these problems. I think we can solve a lot of them.

BARTIROMO: So, the infrastructure announcement was what specifically over the weekend?

GREENBURG: That we're going to -- we're going to build, with a one -- with one road, one belt, what the Chinese are doing, we're going to be competing with them.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Hank, it's great to get your insights on these.

GREENBURG: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

GREENBURG: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Hank Greenberg is the chairman and CEO of C.V. Starr.

President Trump is tweeting on Bob Woodward's new book this morning, here's what he just wrote. Isn't it a shame that someone can write an article or book totally make up stories and form a picture of a person that is literally the exact opposite of the fact, and get away with it without retribution or cost. Don't know why Washington politicians don't change libel laws.

All right, we'll take a short break. When we come back, Toyota is recalling over a million cars across the world. The new warning from vehicles plagued with a fire risk coming up.

And then a heartwarming cup of Joe. Details on the first Starbucks reportedly run entirely by senior citizens. Back in a moment, right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. An American hero killed in an insider attack in Afghanistan. Cheryl Casone with the detail, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Maria, 42-year-old army command sergeant major Timothy Bolyard was killed by a member of the Afghan National Police. He was the highest enlisted soldier supporting the Trump's administration new advisor brigade. The command sergeant major awarded the bronze star, the nation's fourth highest military decoration on six different occasions. Two were given with valor, meaning they were granted for heroic acts. He was on his 13th deployment overseas.

Well, another headlines this morning, Toyota is recalling more than one million vehicles to repair a problem with the electrical system that could start a fire. The affected models include Prius and C-HR Crossover, SUVs, most of these were made in Japan between June 2015 and last May. Toyota spokesman says 192,000 Prius cars are going to be recalled here in the United States.

Taking a look at shares of Toyota, stock is trading almost one percent lower in the premarket right now.

Well, the CDC says that 30 more people have gotten sick after eating Kellogg's Honey Smacks cereal. That's a total of 130 cases now over 36 states. And that includes 34 people that have been hospitalized.

Despite the salmonella contamination that was linked to the cereal Honey Smacks is still being sold in some stores. In June, Kellogg's recalled over a million cases of the cereal from more than 30 states due to the potential contamination.

Well, now the CDC is adding three more states to the list that have reported cases of illness now including Delaware, Maine, and Minnesota. Shares of Kellogg are up about five percent so far this year.

And here's a first, if you're a certain age, looking for a job, you're in luck. Starbucks is letting only senior citizens run one of its cafes in Mexico City. This is the first in the company's history. This is a result of a partnership between Starbucks and the National Institute for the Elderly which offers of course, jobs to seniors. Starbucks Mexico reportedly plans to provide employment to 100 senior adults by next year.

Taking a look at the stock right now, down seven percent this year.

By the way, Maria, all of the employees, it's going to be an entirely senior citizen run store, they have to be or they are right now between the ages of 55 and 60 and they get medical benefits.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

CASONE: My God.

BARTIROMO: We all love that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: The nicest person I've run into in an Apple store was this retired older gentleman who helped me and who knew more than the guy who was maybe 50 years his junior.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic.

MCDOWELL: It was awesome.

BARTIROMO: I love it. Thanks, Cheryl.

Coming up, the economy under Trump, we are taking a closer look ahead of the August jobs report. We got the preview Big Friday this week. That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets have been under pressure this morning. Take a look at Futures, indicating a decline of 90 points on the Dow Jones Industrial average and 27 points on the NASDAQ.

Second quarter growth was pretty impressive. September though is historically a slow month for markets. What will help bolster their confidence?

Joining us now is Troy Gayeski he's senior portfolio manager of SkyBridge Capital. And Troy, it's good to see you this morning.

TROY GAYESKI, SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, SKYBRIDGE CAPITAL: Yes, great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Are you expecting a tough September for markets?

GAYESKI: Well, given the recent run-up we are expecting more consolidation. I mean, if you look at the path of this year we had a huge run-up in January, then a correction and a long period of consolidation. We've only recently made new highs. And now some of the dark clouds are gathering in terms of trade, other issues, slower growth overseas, emerging markets are in the midst of almost a full-blown crisis now.

So, we are expecting a slightly tougher month. That being said, we don't expect a correction north of 10 percent, maybe two to three percent, upside to five. So there's no reason to overreact in the short term. Because the fundamentals of the U.S. economy are still extremely strong.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER & CEO, ROSECLIFF: I agree with you, Troy, on your assessment. But what I -- what I take a bullish stance on is that, you're getting so many negatives in the market. You know, you hear the old expression in the markets climbs the wall.

GAYESKI: Yes.

MURPHY: But we're nowhere close to where everybody is saying, you know, sell your house, get in the market, you need to be in the market with everything you have. So I think as long as that concern and worry is out there, it's a bullish sign for the market.

GAYESKI: We don't disagree over the medium to long term. The point is, over the next week or two, with some of these issues festering, particularly overseas, you see Indonesia been the latest emerging mark to get taken down last night and today, that just argues for softness over the next week or two. But over the medium to long-term, we expect this bull market to continue and newer highs to be made.

BOB NARDELLI, FORMER CEO, CHRYSLER AND HOME DEPOT: We were talking earlier, some of the areas that you're now focusing on relative to investment. Why don't you share with us what those are?

GAYESKI: Yes. So, we continue to focus on the credit quality of regional community banks. You know, if you think of the massive regulatory relief that's occurred there, the benefits of from tax reform, there's also benefits in terms of better lending margins there than the larger banks.

What you have is a setup where you can make, you know, high single digit cash flows. Because these are floating rate securities, they're still low dollar prices. And at the same time, you're going to get paid your principal back faster. So, we think that's -- you know, a low teens type return profile for the next several years with much less downside risk if we do have a surprise bear market or recession.

BARTIROMO: We got the Friday job reports out this week.

GAYESKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: The August jobs numbers. You say if we see less or fewer than 200,000 jobs it signals a path toward overheating the market.

GAYESKI: Well, the point there is if, say we get a 150 number and at the same time unemployment drops 3.7 to 3.8. What that means is there's a little more pressure on the Fed to hike because we don't have as many marginally attached workers to pull back in.

That's been really the big success that, you know, that Janet Yellen has, is pulling marginally attached workers and now Jay Powell back in the labor force, running things little hotter than perhaps a lot of the Phillips curve crowd would've thought in terms of inflation.

BARTIROMO: Do you want to short this market right here?

GAYESKI: No, it's a -- it's a losing bet.

BARTIROMO: OK. Yes, because you look at where technology is, trillion dollar companies, now Amazon joins the trillion dollar club.

GAYESKI: Yes, shorting tech in the strike is the way to bullet fast.

NARDELLI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Good quote.

GAYESKI: You just ask -- you just ask people from the 90s.

BARTIROMO: Troy Gayeski.

Stay with Fox Business. Our special coverage of jobs in America, Friday morning 8:00 a.m. eastern right here. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday September 5th. Your top stories right now just after 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, September 5th. Your top stories right now, just after 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Tech goes to Capitol Hill today. Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg and Twitter's Jack Dorsey will be questioned this morning on possible foreign influence over social media and accusations of political bias.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I don't think it's about election. I think what it's really about free speech.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If the conservatives just leave, then only the liberal voices will be on Twitter. And Twitter's a very powerful tool.

A world with the United States and China as allies is a much safer world than if we're not. And that's an important part of this whole conversation.

BARTIROMO: So, what do you want to say to President Trump as he deals with the leadership in China right now?

GREENBURG: We've got to find a solution. It can't be just increasing tariffs. I mean that's -- China has to recognize, they have to give foreign companies equality in doing business in China, same as they want in our country. And that has to happen. I think most Chinese businessmen understand that now.

BARTIROMO: Because isn't it true that China is now using its economic power for its military complex? You know, we spoke with Devin Nunes, the chairman of the Intel Committee on the House, and he basically said they're creating military bases and complexes right up to sea level, getting their -- the best position across the world, not even near Asia.

GREENBURG: Well, I'm not too worried about that part of it. I think what they've done in the South China Sea is I'm concern.

BARTIROMO: Why? Tell us about that.

GREENBURG: Yes, these little islands that they claim that China over the - - over the centuries had owned, there's no -- there's no evidence of that. If they went to court, in the -- in the world court, and they were denied that they had the right to that, they went ahead anyway.

And it was during the -- during the Obama administration, we did nothing. And now it would be -- now it would be very difficult to extract them from those -- from those islands.

BARTIROMO: In your view, will the U.S. be successful in opening up markets, in getting to -- getting China to change its behavior?

GREENBURG: I'm not sure they'll change their behavior willingly but I think there'll be change in many areas.

BARTIROMO: And if there isn't? They're the two largest economies in the world.

GREENBURG: Then we'll -- then we'll have a trade conflict.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GREENBURG: And it's not in our interest, not in their interest. I saw the other day, -- you now, China is building this one road, one infrastructure around the world.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GREENBURG: I see that we're going to do $60 billion of that ourselves. We just announced it over the weekend.

And so, you know, we do have some conflicts. That's inevitable. But doesn't have to mean that we're enemies. Doesn't have to mean that we don't try to solve these problems. I think we can solve a lot of them.

BARTIROMO: So, the infrastructure announcement was what specifically over the weekend?

GREENBURG: That we're going to -- we're going to build, with a one -- with one road, one belt, what the Chinese are doing, we're going to be competing with them.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Hank, it's great to get your insights on these.

GREENBURG: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

GREENBURG: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Hank Greenberg is the chairman and CEO of C.V. Starr.

President Trump is tweeting on Bob Woodward's new book this morning, here's what he just wrote. Isn't it a shame that someone can write an article or book totally make up stories and form a picture of a person that is literally the exact opposite of the fact, and get away with it without retribution or cost. Don't know why Washington politicians don't change libel laws.

All right, we'll take a short break. When we come back, Toyota is recalling over a million cars across the world. The new warning from vehicles plagued with a fire risk coming up.

And then a heartwarming cup of Joe. Details on the first Starbucks reportedly run entirely by senior citizens. Back in a moment, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. An American hero killed in an insider attack in Afghanistan. Cheryl Casone with the detail, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, Maria, 42-year-old army command sergeant major Timothy Bolyard was killed by a member of the Afghan National Police. He was the highest enlisted soldier supporting the Trump's administration new advisor brigade. The command sergeant major awarded the bronze star, the nation's fourth highest military decoration on six different occasions. Two were given with valor, meaning they were granted for heroic acts. He was on his 13th deployment overseas.

Well, another headlines this morning, Toyota is recalling more than one million vehicles to repair a problem with the electrical system that could start a fire. The affected models include Prius and C-HR Crossover, SUVs, most of these were made in Japan between June 2015 and last May. Toyota spokesman says 192,000 Prius cars are going to be recalled here in the United States.

Taking a look at shares of Toyota, stock is trading almost one percent lower in the premarket right now.

Well, the CDC says that 30 more people have gotten sick after eating Kellogg's Honey Smacks cereal. That's a total of 130 cases now over 36 states. And that includes 34 people that have been hospitalized.

Despite the salmonella contamination that was linked to the cereal Honey Smacks is still being sold in some stores. In June, Kellogg's recalled over a million cases of the cereal from more than 30 states due to the potential contamination.

Well, now the CDC is adding three more states to the list that have reported cases of illness now including Delaware, Maine, and Minnesota. Shares of Kellogg are up about five percent so far this year.

And here's a first, if you're a certain age, looking for a job, you're in luck. Starbucks is letting only senior citizens run one of its cafes in Mexico City. This is the first in the company's history. This is a result of a partnership between Starbucks and the National Institute for the Elderly which offers of course, jobs to seniors. Starbucks Mexico reportedly plans to provide employment to 100 senior adults by next year.

Taking a look at the stock right now, down seven percent this year.

By the way, Maria, all of the employees, it's going to be an entirely senior citizen run store, they have to be or they are right now between the ages of 55 and 60 and they get medical benefits.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

CASONE: My God.

BARTIROMO: We all love that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: The nicest person I've run into in an Apple store was this retired older gentleman who helped me and who knew more than the guy who was maybe 50 years his junior.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic.

MCDOWELL: It was awesome.

BARTIROMO: I love it. Thanks, Cheryl.

Coming up, the economy under Trump, we are taking a closer look ahead of the August jobs report. We got the preview Big Friday this week. That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets have been under pressure this morning. Take a look at Futures, indicating a decline of 90 points on the Dow Jones Industrial average and 27 points on the NASDAQ.

Second quarter growth was pretty impressive. September though is historically a slow month for markets. What will help bolster their confidence?

Joining us now is Troy Gayeski he's senior portfolio manager of SkyBridge Capital. And Troy, it's good to see you this morning.

TROY GAYESKI, SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, SKYBRIDGE CAPITAL: Yes, great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Are you expecting a tough September for markets?

GAYESKI: Well, given the recent run-up we are expecting more consolidation. I mean, if you look at the path of this year we had a huge run-up in January, then a correction and a long period of consolidation. We've only recently made new highs. And now some of the dark clouds are gathering in terms of trade, other issues, slower growth overseas, emerging markets are in the midst of almost a full-blown crisis now.

So, we are expecting a slightly tougher month. That being said, we don't expect a correction north of 10 percent, maybe two to three percent, upside to five. So there's no reason to overreact in the short term. Because the fundamentals of the U.S. economy are still extremely strong.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER & CEO, ROSECLIFF: I agree with you, Troy, on your assessment. But what I -- what I take a bullish stance on is that, you're getting so many negatives in the market. You know, you hear the old expression in the markets climbs the wall.

GAYESKI: Yes.

MURPHY: But we're nowhere close to where everybody is saying, you know, sell your house, get in the market, you need to be in the market with everything you have. So I think as long as that concern and worry is out there, it's a bullish sign for the market.

GAYESKI: We don't disagree over the medium to long term. The point is, over the next week or two, with some of these issues festering, particularly overseas, you see Indonesia been the latest emerging mark to get taken down last night and today, that just argues for softness over the next week or two. But over the medium to long-term, we expect this bull market to continue and newer highs to be made.

BOB NARDELLI, FORMER CEO, CHRYSLER AND HOME DEPOT: We were talking earlier, some of the areas that you're now focusing on relative to investment. Why don't you share with us what those are?

GAYESKI: Yes. So, we continue to focus on the credit quality of regional community banks. You know, if you think of the massive regulatory relief that's occurred there, the benefits of from tax reform, there's also benefits in terms of better lending margins there than the larger banks.

What you have is a setup where you can make, you know, high single digit cash flows. Because these are floating rate securities, they're still low dollar prices. And at the same time, you're going to get paid your principal back faster. So, we think that's -- you know, a low teens type return profile for the next several years with much less downside risk if we do have a surprise bear market or recession.

BARTIROMO: We got the Friday job reports out this week.

GAYESKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: The August jobs numbers. You say if we see less or fewer than 200,000 jobs it signals a path toward overheating the market.

GAYESKI: Well, the point there is if, say we get a 150 number and at the same time unemployment drops 3.7 to 3.8. What that means is there's a little more pressure on the Fed to hike because we don't have as many marginally attached workers to pull back in.

That's been really the big success that, you know, that Janet Yellen has, is pulling marginally attached workers and now Jay Powell back in the labor force, running things little hotter than perhaps a lot of the Phillips curve crowd would've thought in terms of inflation.

BARTIROMO: Do you want to short this market right here?

GAYESKI: No, it's a -- it's a losing bet.

BARTIROMO: OK. Yes, because you look at where technology is, trillion dollar companies, now Amazon joins the trillion dollar club.

GAYESKI: Yes, shorting tech in the strike is the way to bullet fast.

NARDELLI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Good quote.

GAYESKI: You just ask -- you just ask people from the 90s.

BARTIROMO: Troy Gayeski.

Stay with Fox Business. Our special coverage of jobs in America, Friday morning 8:00 a.m. eastern right here. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday September 5th. Your top stories right now just after 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END
